message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Dynamic Event-Triggered Distributed Coordination Control and its Applications: A Survey of Trends and Techniques
Paper Abstract: Distributed coordination control is the current trend in networked systems and finds prosperous applications across a variety of fields, such as smart grids and intelligent transportation systems. One fundamental issue in coordinating and controlling a large group of distributed and networked agents is the influence of intermittent interagent interactions caused by constrained communication resources. Event-triggered communication scheduling stands out as a promising enabler to strike a balance between the desired control performance and the satisfactory resource efficiency. What distinguishes dynamic event-triggered scheduling from traditional static event-triggered scheduling is that the triggering mechanism can be dynamically adjusted over time in accordance with both available system information and additional dynamic variables. This article provides an up-to-date overview of dynamic event-triggered distributed coordination control. The motivation of dynamic event-triggered scheduling is first introduced in the context of distributed coordination control. Then some techniques of dynamic event-triggered distributed coordination control are discussed in detail. Implementation and design issues are well addressed. Furthermore, this article exemplifies two applications of dynamic event-triggered distributed coordination control in the fields of microgrids and automated vehicles. Several challenges are suggested to direct the future research.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed the web search for "networked control systems." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

A networked control system (NCS) is a control system wherein the control loops are closed through a communication network.(no content)The defining feature of an NCS is that control and feedback signals are exchanged among the system's components in the form of information packages through a network.

## Key Characteristics and Challenges

The insertion of the communication network in the feedback control loop makes the analysis and design of an NCS complex, since it imposes additional time delays in control loops or possibility of packages loss.(no content)New control strategies, kinematics of the actuators in the systems, reliability and security of communications, bandwidth allocation, development of data communication protocols, corresponding fault detection and fault tolerant control strategies, real-time information collection and efficient processing of sensors data are some of the relative topics studied in depth.

## Wireless Applications

Wireless networks, e.g. Bluetooth, Zigbee, and Z-Wave, are used in NCS. The term wireless networked control system (WNCS) is often used in this connection.

## Modern Applications

Critical infrastructure is controlled by a web of interconnected control systems, either architecture termed as distributed control systems (DCS) or supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA), though the application of control is moving toward a more decentralized state.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's information about intelligent transportation systems:

## What is an Intelligent Transportation System?

An intelligent transportation system (ITS) is an advanced application that aims to provide services relating to different modes of transport and traffic management and enable users to be better informed and make safer, more coordinated, and 'smarter' use of transport networks.

## Key Technologies and Components

Intelligent transport systems incorporate a wide range of technologies, from basic management systems such as car navigation, traffic signal control, and variable-message signs, to more advanced, interconnected applications.

The system includes various types of applications:

- **Monitoring and Enforcement**: Technologies like automatic number plate recognition, speed cameras, and security CCTV systems are used for traffic monitoring and law enforcement.

- **Real-Time Information**: A major application is providing real-time information to passengers, such as predicting the arrival time of public transport, which is achieved by processing data collected from transit vehicles with telematics and GPS tracking units.

- **Cooperative Systems**: A significant trend in ITS is the development of Cooperative ITS (C-ITS), where vehicles and infrastructure are interconnected with data shared through vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) and vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) communication, allowing for real-time hazard warnings and coordinated traffic flow.

## Historical Context

This new mixture of infrastructure and technology was identified as an intelligent transportation system (ITS) and was the centerpiece of the 1991 ISTEA act.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about smart grids:

## Definition

A smart grid is an enhancement of the 20th century electrical grid, using two-way communications and distributed intelligent devices. More specifically, a smart grid is an electric grid that has been digitized to enable two-way communication between producers and consumers.

## Key Components and Features

Research is mainly focused on three systems of a smart grid – the infrastructure system, the management system, and the protection system.(no content)Numerous contributions to the overall improvement of energy infrastructure efficiency are anticipated from the deployment of smart grid technology, in particular including demand-side management.

A smart grid includes various technologies such as advanced metering infrastructure, smart distribution boards and circuit breakers integrated with home control and demand response, and renewable energy resources including the capacity to charge electric vehicle batteries or larger arrays of batteries.

## Benefits

The potential benefits from a smart grid include increased reliability, more efficient electricity use, better economics, and improved sustainability. Additionally, the improved flexibility of the smart grid permits greater penetration of highly variable renewable energy sources such as solar power and wind power.

## Global Development

The concept of a smart grid began to emerge in the early 2000s.(no content)In the 21st century, some developing countries like China, India, and Brazil were seen as pioneers of smart grid deployment.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about distributed coordination control:

## Overview

The term "distributed coordination control" encompasses several different contexts:

### Distributed Control Systems (DCS)

A distributed control system (DCS) is a computerized control system for a process or plant usually with many control loops, in which autonomous controllers are distributed throughout the system, but there is no central operator supervisory control.(no content)The DCS concept increases reliability and reduces installation costs by localizing control functions near the process plant, with remote monitoring and supervision.

### Decentralized Control

Distributed control is a form of control in which each component of the system is equally responsible for contributing to the global, complex behaviour by acting on local information in the appropriate manner.(no content)Decentralised systems are intricately linked to the idea of self-organisation—a phenomenon in which local interactions between components of a system establish order and coordination to achieve global goals without a central commanding influence.

### Wireless Network Coordination

In the context of networking, Distributed coordination function (DCF) is the fundamental medium access control (MAC) technique of the IEEE 802.11-based WLAN standard (including Wi-Fi).

The search results show that distributed coordination control appears in industrial process control, decentralized systems design, and wireless communications, with the common theme being the distribution of control responsibilities across multiple independent components rather than relying on a single central authority.

Distributed control is a form of control in which each component of the system is equally responsible for contributing to the global, complex behaviour by acting on local information in the appropriate manner.(no content)Decentralised systems are intricately linked to the idea of self-organisation—a phenomenon in which local interactions between components of a system establish order and coordination to achieve global goals without a central commanding influence.

### Wireless Network Coordination

In the context of networking, Distributed coordination function (DCF) is the fundamental medium access control (MAC) technique of the IEEE 802.11-based WLAN standard (including Wi-Fi).

The search results show that distributed coordination control appears in industrial process control, decentralized systems design, and wireless communications, with the common theme being the distribution of control responsibilities across multiple independent components rather than relying on a single central authority.

## Event-Triggered Communication

Based on the search results, here's what I found about event-triggered communication:

**Definition and Overview**

Event-triggered communication is a communication approach where data is sent in response to specific events, as used in systems like FlexRay which split operation into static and dynamic segments for event-triggered and time-triggered communications.

**How It Works**

In the dynamic segment, nodes take control of the bus as available, allowing event-triggered behavior. This contrasts with time-triggered systems that operate on predetermined schedules.

**Comparison with Time-Triggered Systems**

Event-triggered (ET) systems can be viewed as more general architectures compared to time-triggered systems, which are a subset of event-triggered architecture.(no content)Implementation of an ET system typically involves use of multiple interrupts, each associated with specific periodic events or aperiodic events such as the arrival of messages over a communication bus at random points in time.

**Applications**

Event-triggered communication is mainly used in aeronautic and automotive sectors.(no content)FlexRay, which supports event-triggered communication, supports data rates up to 10 Mbit/s and can have two independent data channels for fault-tolerance.

In essence, event-triggered communication enables systems to send data reactively in response to specific events or conditions, rather than following a fixed time-based schedule.

Here's what I found about microgrids:

## Definition and Basic Concept

A microgrid is a local electrical grid with defined electrical boundaries, acting as a single and controllable entity.(no content)It is able to operate in grid-connected and off-grid modes.

## Key Characteristics

A microgrid is a localized grouping of electricity generation, energy storage, and loads that normally operates connected to a traditional centralized grid (macrogrid), with a single point of common coupling that can be disconnected, allowing the microgrid to then function autonomously.(no content)Microgrid generation resources can include stationary batteries, fuel cells, solar, wind, or other energy sources.

## Benefits and Applications

Microgrids can disconnect from the centralized grid and operate autonomously, strengthen grid resilience, and help mitigate grid disturbances.(no content)Stand-alone microgrids are used where power transmission and distribution from a major centralized energy source is too far and costly to operate, and they offer an option for rural electrification in remote areas and on smaller geographical islands.

Web search results for query: "scheduling algorithm resource"

Links: [{"title":"Scheduling (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scheduling_(computing)"},{"title":"Interval scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interval_scheduling"},{"title":"Round-robin scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Round-robin_scheduling"},{"title":"Category:Scheduling algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Scheduling_algorithms"},{"title":"Starvation (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starvation_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Job-shop scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Job-shop_scheduling"},{"title":"Slurm Workload Manager - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slurm_Workload_Manager"},{"title":"List scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_scheduling"},{"title":"Rate-monotonic scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rate-monotonic_scheduling"},{"title":"Earliest deadline first scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earliest_deadline_first_scheduling"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of scheduling algorithms and resource management:

## Definition

A scheduling discipline (also called scheduling policy or scheduling algorithm) is an algorithm used for distributing resources among parties which simultaneously and asynchronously request them.

## Key Purposes

The main purposes of scheduling algorithms are to minimize resource starvation and to ensure fairness amongst the parties utilizing the resources.(no content)Scheduling disciplines are used in routers (to handle packet traffic) as well as in operating systems (to share CPU time among both threads and processes), disk drives (I/O scheduling), printers (print spooler), most embedded systems, etc.

## Common Scheduling Algorithms

**Round-Robin Scheduling:** Time slices (also known as time quanta) are assigned to each process in equal portions and in circular order, handling all processes without priority (also known as cyclic executive).

**FIFO/FCFS:** First in, first out (FIFO), also known as first come, first served (FCFS), is the simplest scheduling algorithm. FIFO simply queues processes in the order that they arrive in the ready queue.

**Earliest Deadline First (EDF):** Earliest deadline first (EDF) or least time to go is a dynamic priority scheduling algorithm used in real-time operating systems to place processes in a priority queue. The queue will be searched for the process closest to its deadline, and this process is the next to be scheduled for execution.

**List Scheduling:** List scheduling is a greedy algorithm for Identical-machines scheduling. The input to this algorithm is a list of jobs that should be executed on a set of m machines.

Links: [{"title":"Vehicular automation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicular_automation"},{"title":"Self-driving car - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-driving_car"},{"title":"History of self-driving cars - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_self-driving_cars"},{"title":"List of predictions for autonomous Tesla vehicles by Elon Musk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_predictions_for_autonomous_Tesla_vehicles_by_Elon_Musk"},{"title":"Robotaxi - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotaxi"},{"title":"Zoox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zoox"},{"title":"Regulation of self-driving cars - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulation_of_self-driving_cars"},{"title":"List of self-driving system suppliers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_self-driving_system_suppliers"},{"title":"Unmanned ground vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_ground_vehicle"},{"title":"Cruise (autonomous vehicle) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cruise_(autonomous_vehicle)"}]

I've completed the web search for "automated vehicle autonomous". Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Overview
Assisted vehicles are semi-autonomous, whereas vehicles that can travel without a human operator are autonomous.

## Automation Levels
The Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) classifies road vehicle autonomy in six levels: Level 1 is driver assistance where the vehicle controls steering or speed autonomously in specific circumstances; Level 2 is partial automation where the vehicle controls both steering and speed autonomously in specific circumstances; Level 3 is conditional automation where the vehicle controls both steering and speed under normal environmental conditions but requires the driver to be ready to take control; Level 4 is high automation where the vehicle travels autonomously under normal environmental conditions without requiring driver oversight; and Level 5 is full autonomy where the vehicle can complete travel autonomously in any environmental conditions.

## Technology & Components
Autonomous vehicle software generally contains several different modules that work together to enable self-driving capabilities. The perception module ingests and processes data from various sensors, such cameras, LIDAR, RADAR, and ultrasonic SONAR, to create a comprehensive understanding of the vehicle's surroundings. The localization module uses 3D point cloud data, GPS, IMU, and mapping information to determine the vehicle's precise position, including its orientation, velocity, and angular rate. The planning module takes inputs from both perception and localization to compute actions to take, such as velocity and steering angle outputs.

## Current Market Status
As of August 2023, vehicles operating at Level 3 and above were an insignificant market factor; as of early 2024, Honda leases a Level 3 car in Japan, and Mercedes sells two Level 3 cars in Germany, California and Nevada.

Web search results for query: "control system feedback"

Links: [{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"},{"title":"Control loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_loop"},{"title":"Negative feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_feedback"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Open-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-loop_controller"},{"title":"Servomechanism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Servomechanism"},{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of control system feedback:

## Definition and Purpose

A closed-loop controller or feedback controller is a control loop which incorporates feedback, in contrast to an open-loop controller or non-feedback controller.(no content)A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

## How Feedback Works

Process inputs (e.g., voltage applied to an electric motor) have an effect on the process outputs (e.g., speed or torque of the motor), which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result (the control signal) is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.(no content)The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, or SP-PV error, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Advantages Over Open-Loop Control

Control systems that include some sensing of the results they are trying to achieve are making use of feedback and can adapt to varying circumstances to some extent.(no content)Closed-loop controllers have the following advantages over open-loop controllers: disturbance rejection (such as hills in the cruise control example above) guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties, when the model structure does not match perfectly the real process and the model parameters are not exact.

## Types of Feedback

Positive feedback occurs if the signal feedback from output is in phase with the input signal, while negative feedback occurs if the signal feedback is out of phase by 180° with respect to the input signal.

## Practical Example

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was done:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Survey

This paper is a **survey** - it provides an overview of dynamic event-triggered distributed coordination control techniques, applications, and challenges without proposing novel methods.

**Triples Extracted:** 10 entities with their relationships

| Entity | Type | Relation | Purpose |
|--------|------|----------|---------|
| Distributed control system | concept | uses | Foundational framework for coordination |
| Event-driven architecture | method | proposes | Core technique for event-triggered scheduling |
| Networked control system | concept | uses | Framework for network-based control loops |
| Smart grid | task | uses | Application domain demonstrating real-world use |
| Intelligent transportation system | task | uses | Application area for vehicle coordination |
| Microgrid | task | uses | Specific application for energy distribution |
| Vehicular automation | task | uses | Application for automated vehicles |
| Scheduling (computing) | method | proposes | Technique for managing event triggering |
| Control theory | concept | uses | Theoretical foundation |
| Closed-loop controller | method | uses | Feedback mechanism for control performance |

**Validation:** ✅ Passed all checks
- Paper type correctly set to "survey"
- All 10 triples properly configured with valid Wikipedia URLs
- Entity types balanced: 3 concepts, 3 methods, 4 tasks

Sources:
- [Distributed control system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_control_system)
- [Event-driven architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_architecture)
- [Networked control system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Networked_control_system)
- [Smart grid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_grid)
- [Intelligent transportation system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_transportation_system)
- [Microgrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microgrid)
